page.title: 16Salmon Fishing on the Tweed
page.content: When the net is almost across the river it is towed downstream by the boat on the river and by the man onthe bank.When the boat is opposite the landing,Usually a gently sloping beach of gravel,the coble is rowed across releasing another rope attached to the other end of the net,known as ths "stirrup". This rope is then puled in as quickly as possible so trapping any fish who swim up the wings of the net to a bag on the end where they remain until landed. The Salmon Company has to continued to keep abreast of the times with modern premises and plant.They have their own fisheries on the river while others are owned privately and let.The fish are collected each morning by the fish merchant from Berwick or by the Salmon Company.Cobles were tradition- made of wood but are now made of glass
